newsitem.title: FRANCE: Juppe, Kohl reaffirm plans to press ahead with EMU.
newsitem.headline: Juppe, Kohl reaffirm plans to press ahead with EMU.

text.p: French Prime Minister Alain Juppe and German Chancellor Helmut Kohl reaffirmed their determination in a telephone conversation on Thursday to press ahead with European monetary union as scheduled.

A day after ex-president Valery Giscard d'Estaing called for a weaker franc, a statement from Juppe's office said Kohl and Juppe also stated the current franc-mark exchange rate was in line with economic fundamentals in both countries.
"Prime Minister Alain Juppe and Chancellor Helmut Kohl spoke by telephone on the afternoon of November 21.
"They reaffirmed France and Germany's commitment to launch Economic and Monetary Union within the timetable and criteria fixed by the (Maastricht) treaty," the statement said.
"The prime minister and the chancellor noted that the current exchange rate between the franc and the mark corresponded to the fundamentals of the two national economies," the statement added.

Giscard d'Estaing called in a magazine article for a sharp depreciation in the franc against the dollar, implying a similar big fall against the mark, to revive growth and employment. His comments have slightly weakened the franc against the mark.
